title: Man Utd have avoided showing players too much Liverpool footage in case it 'frightens them to death'
text:
Manchester United have refused to show players' footage of Liverpool games in case it 'frightens them to death.'

Liverpool have won their first eight Premier League games while Manchester United have made their worst start to a league season in 30 years.

Manchester United's assistant manager Mike Phelan told The Sun: 'We got the whole team together from the internationals.

Assistant manager Mike Phelan said they avoided showing players too much Liverpool footage

'Some players have come back in better moods than others because they have qualified, so we've brought them together and shown them a few things.

'We've tried not to show them too much of Liverpool. It is more about who we are because if you go down that road you'd frighten them to death.'

He added: 'We have come back in good nick. We are reduced in numbers but it will be an interesting game.'

Manchester United could drop to 18 points behind the league leaders with defeat to Liverpool

Manchester United will be hoping to break Liverpool's 100 per cent winning record in the league this season.

Defeat for United, would not only strengthen their rival's title chances but would mean that the Red Devils would be 18 points behind the Merseyside club after just nine games.

United are expected to welcome back Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Victor Lindelof, Luke Shaw and Anthony Martial from the disappointing 1-0 defeat at Newcastle before the international break.

However, Paul Pogba is set to miss out with an ankle injury and goalkeeper David De Gea is ready to be replaced by 2014 World Cup finalist Sergio Romero after pulling his hamstring playing for Spain.

Phelan was Sir Alex Ferguson's right hand man during better days for the team where he was part of three title-winning teams. He left shortly after Ferguson retired but rejoined the club in December 2018.
description: Manchester United's assistant manager Mike Phelan has said they have avoided showing too much footage of Liverpool before the crucial game. Liverpool could go 18 points ahead of their rivals with a victory.
